comments.commentBody: See post #6 for a philosophical problem about field philosophy.

I will let Andrew speak for himself here.  But I do have to say something in response to point #3 in the above post, Prof. Frodeman.  I realize that you are specifically challenging the implication that philosophical works have to be long to be of value.  But it is silly to invoke Wittgenstein and Nietzsche here!  For whether one agrees with them or not in this judgment, there is no doubt they would have nothing but utter disdain for "field philosophy" as you describe it.   Both have an extremely high minded conception of the proper task of philosophy (again, whether rightly or wrongly).  These are not the figures you want to bring in as your potential allies in any way, shape, or form.

I think the Yankees should hold the line - why should Jeter get so much money in a down economy?  These salaries are ultimately paid for by the fans - expensive seats or too many commercials is the price we all pay for overpaid ballplayers.

I am a Yankees fan and a Jeter admirer. Here is a possible framework for negotiation.

1. Standard: He should be paid based on his market value going forward. A vehicle for rewarding him for past performance is discussed in 7 below.

2. Elements of Value: His market value includes both playing and non-playing contributions.

3. Playing Value: The playing contribution is unknown. We know that in general position players aged 36 perform worse than they did before. The reasonable approach is to pay based on his 2010 performance, with bonuses for reaching standards, perhaps 200 hits, .330 batting average, .450 slugging percentage, .400 on-base percentage, 20 home runs, .850 OPS+, and some fielding criterion (not the Golden Glove). So start by looking at what other shortstops are getting who are negotiating this year and had similar years. It appears that is well below $15 million per year for three years. Then look at players under contract. Hanley Ramirez (27-30 in 2011-2014) in comparison is getting $11 million for 2011 and ($57 million for 2011-2014). Jimmy Rollins (32 in 2011) is getting $8.5 million. It stretches credulity that Jeter could be worth much more as a player in 2011 than either of these all-stars.

4. Non-playing value: The non-playing contribution is substantial. This is much more if he is a Yankee than if he is with another team. First, it is reasonable to conclude more tickets to Yankee games will be sold with Jeter as a Yankee (and that increment is greater than if he was with another team). If you assume 1000 tickets at $50.00 per ticket, that is $8,100,000 for 162 games. Some of that should go to Jeter. Second, his presence will help the Yankees sell more merchandise. How much more? The parties should be able to estimate and allocate some share to Jeter. Third, he improves the performance of the other players. How much? 5 games per year? 10? I don’t know. But Jeter and the Yankees know roughly, and he should be compensated for that. If his performance declines further, all these contributions will shrink. Do these add $5 million to his value? $10 million?

5. Babe Ruth: Per ESPN, Close told the New York Daily News on Sunday, "There's a reason the Yankees themselves have stated Derek Jeter is their modern-day Babe Ruth.” I Googled this and could not find the Yankees stating that. So I am assuming that is Mr. Close' opinion.

Jeter is a Hall of Fame player. And I understand he is superior (from my perspective) to Ruth regarding alcohol and philandering. But doesn’t Mr. Close realize that only Lou Gehrig and Joe DiMaggio were close to Ruth in their value to the team? A good analogy is saying Hall of Famer Carl Yastrzemski was a modern day Ted Williams. Equally absurd. There are levels of greatness and Jeter is in the second tier of Yankees. It is more accurate, and no small praise, to say Jeter is similar to Mantle and Berra in his value.

6. Phased reductions after rejection of offer: If Close asked for $23-24 million for 4 or 5 seasons, it is a rejection of the Yankee’s 3-year @$15 million offer. I think it is far more money than the above criteria indicate is reasonable. As a prior commenter suggested, the Yankees should reduce their offer by a fixed amount each week until agreement is reached. Based on the framework above, a base of $12 million for three years, plus incentives, is reasonable. (If disincentives were allowed, it would also be reasonable to reduce payment for failure to reach lesser goals.) As Cashman said, Jeter should test the market. Then he will likely return to the Yankees because of his greater value for that team.

7. Trust fund: The Yankees paid him for prior performance. If not in violation of MLB rules or the collective bargaining agreement, the many fans who believe he should be paid in 2011 for his prior contributions could set up a trust fund or other facility to compensate him. 50,000 people could pay $100 per year for $5,000,000.

Oh no! You just revealed my secret place. This is indeed a lovely place, and I like the description of it being "plantation style".  Those rockers on the veranda are wonderful. The food, however, could be a little less bland.

Have you ever eaten in a place where the agonized efforts of the chef overshadow the natural taste of good food. This is an example of over cheffing which has become a syndrome of some modern restaurants. Too bad. Lovely room.

"because teams today uniformly employ specialists as kickers, it could obviously stay that way."

How would this practice prevent today's non-kicking offense player from scoring seven touchdowns for 42 points? Just asking...

The teenager who was given all the tools necessary to act out his sick fantasy world is just one more victim of terrorism and the "war" on terrorism.

Unless we face the cold reality that the "war on terror" has metastasized into a multi-trillion dollar enterprise with no end in sight, we will be insuring that we get more of what we're "paying for". Cashflow generates its own perversely inexorable "logic".

All "sides" derive all manner of political and financial profits from the status quo.

What we are doing is insane and utterly unsustainable in the long run. We will bankrupt our economy and destroy our democracy and lose our freedoms if we stay on the current trajectory.
Hmmmm.  FBI was tracking him from the age of 15 and finally got their "man"?

Opinions aside on the rightness or wrongness of the FBI's actions in this case, I am surprised by the number of indignant wails of "entrapment," as if this sting being entrapment would make a difference.

Whether you call it semantics, technicality, precedent, or a cynical modern prison state, you should know by now that in real life there is nothing illegal about "entrapment." Maybe in Hollywood or on Law and Order, but not here.

In some states you can get a prison sentence, fine and felony conviction for (accidentally or negligently) selling cigarettes to a police-hired 17-year old.

There are no rights and no standards that law enforcement can't find a way around. Get a clue.
So congress should be acting on an immigration policy now that Republicans are running the show?
Could someone say Lee Harvey Oswald?

I find it interesting that at least 3 posters have alluded to a non-existent Muslim tipster.  Please re-read the article, there is no mention of a Muslim tipster.  I understand that we all really, really want there to be one, but we shouldn't bend reality to what we want.  Instead, this guy was caught because his emails to a jihadist were intercepted.  Please stop thanking someone you made up in your mind to be politically correct.

I'm sure his parents are very shocked and very sad, like the parents of the Columbine teens who killed their teachers and schoolmates.

Teens are vulnerable, but can also step over the line into violence--especially if destabilized by promises of extreme potency while treated as if they are nothing of importance. They DO know the difference between right and wrong at age 19. And that makes the entrapment argument that many are putting forth less persuasive.

To the writer who wondered what Muslims can do? Maybe a clear exposition of Jihad would help. It seems like such a call to arms. Is it really? And if so, what kind of arms are we talking about?

Although I have not been there is 24 long years, Portland is my favourite city in the United States. In that sense, this feels personal. Seeing immigrants act this way greatly discourages me, especially when creeps like Mr. Mohamed Osman Mohamud cause all of us to endure loss of civil rights and common civility. However, though I have not lived in Oregon since 1977, even then did well enough there, and though I have no idea what the pervasive tone of the place is now, I can imagine that Mr. Mohamud’s alienation might have emerged from how people in Oregon act if they act the way they did several decades ago. I did not have a particularly hard time but I knew many people who did. It was not a place to be Native American, black, poor, or Southern.

When lived there, I knew many fine people but I also witnessed some of the most offensively insular, self-righteous, narrow-minded, racist, uncivil, dull-witted, imperceptive, and insensitive people I have ever known. If the pervasive tone of Beaverton, Oregon is even slightly the way it was some decades ago, I fully understand how Mr. Mohamud might have become alienated. That does not, of course, excuse this little creep. I hope he lives out the rest of his life in the ADX in Colorado. For all of its charm, Portland did leave much to be desired. Beaverton in particular was an awful community.

What a waste of resources, this 19 like most 19 year olds is not a threat to anyone but himself. this was a clear case of entrapment! Hope a jury of his peers have the good sense and courage to tell the FBI in Oregon (who are very idle)that and acquit this hapless child/man.

I'm new to the internet and am still a liitle amazed at all of it's benefits. This forum and others like it are part of what makes this a great society. To the people who blame the FBI and to the people who support it, keep up the good work! Our founding fathers would be very proud of you all for participating and using your freedom of speach.  Don't take it lightly, it was earned in blood.
Hope that he lives a long life in ADX. He is a creep.

The FBI and it's apologists, along with other branches of national security can crow all they want about entrapping an obviously confused, displaced and immature young man, but it still will not excuse the ineptitude, inefficiency and stupid in-fighting that missed all the advance warning signs of 9/11 in the first place. Pathetic, low level "victories" such as this are so obviously designed to appeal to the low IQ Fox News watchers who seem to have missed the point that, once again, American politicians are spilling innocent blood (including American) in a series of pointless and unwinnable wars. Where next? Disrespectful Iran? Or Sarah Palin's North Korean allies, perhaps?

So it looks like another straight up FBI manufactured entrapment case. They find some dumb teenager, give him taxpayer cash and plant some grandiosse scheme in his lame head. Apparently these FBI are not up to the task of catching real criminals.
